thread.title: $A breaks below 73 US cents on China data
thread.title_full: $A breaks below 73 US cents on China data

title: $A breaks below 73 US cents on China data
text:
Fri, Jul 24, 2015, 6:12 PM AEST - Australia Markets closed $A breaks below 73 US cents on China data AAP – 56 minutes ago Print 
The Australian dollar has ended the week at its lowest point in more than six years, weighed down by soft Chinese manufacturing figures. 
At 1700 AEST on Friday, the currency was trading at 73.02 US cents, down from 73.68 cents on Thursday. 
Western Union Business Solutions currency strategist Steven Dooley said it was driven down by disappointing manufacturing data that was "a massive miss" on expectations. 
China's July Purchasing Managers' Index showed activity was at its weakest in 15 months. 
The currency fell sharply with the news to 72.79 US cents, its lowest level since April 2009. 
And Mr Dooley tipped the currency to remain in a precarious situation during the next three to six months. 
"With commodities lower, a US dollar stronger and a massive slowdown in China it's very difficult to see a way out for the Aussie at the moment," he said. 
"We have a number of analyst forecasts for an Aussie dollar at 65 or 66 (US cents) at the end of the year, and once the US starts raising rates that's actually very likely." 
At 1700 AEST, the Australian dollar was at 90.46 Japanese yen, down from Thursday's close of 91.36 yen, and at 66.44 euro cents, down from 67.39 euro cents. 
The Australian bond market has bolstered, tracking trends on international markets. 
Commonwealth Bank fixed income quantitative strategist Philip Brown said a moderate global overnight rally was the biggest driver for the local market. 
"(That was) on the back of the US equity market weakness," he said. 
This was helped by Friday morning's better than expected government bond tender, he said. 
The Australian Office of Financial Management sold $900 million of April 21, 2025, Treasury bonds. 
"It wasn't massively strong but the two previous were a little weak in spots and there was a fear we'd get a really weak one," Mr Brown said. 
"When you're fearing the worst, nondescript is actually pretty good." 
At 1630 AEST on Friday, the September 2015 10-year bond futures contract was trading at 97.150 (implying a yield of 2.850 per cent), up from 97.105 (2.895 per cent) on Thursday. 
The September 2015 three-year bond futures contract was at 98.100 (1.900 per cent), up from 98.030 (1.970 per cent). @y7finance on Twitter, become a fan on Facebook Labor takes on wealthy, multinationals AAP
